day_1.title: Where does public sector data come from?
day_1.text:
Around the world, 2.5 quintillion bytes (2.5 x 1018 bytes) of data are created every day, with 90 per cent of the data in the world generated in the last two years alone (IBM, 2016). The Government of Canada generates and holds a vast amount and diverse array of data, including spatial data, operational data, transactional service data, and data collected from or about citizens and businesses.

Through the power of data, public servants can fundamentally transform governments by changing the way they operate, make decisions and deliver services. To learn more about how the Government is using data check out the GC Data Strategy.

day_2.text: According to the Information and Communications Technology Council (ICTC) ‘With the increasing use and relevance of technology across all sectors of the economy, Digital+Data has evolved into a thriving, almost self-contained economy of its own. Just a few years ago, a major headline dubbed “data [as] the new oil”, effectively identifying it as a virtual, endlessly renewable natural resource.’ Take a look at the  highlights of ICTC’s perspectives on a data economy strategy.

day_4.title: API Store
day_4.text:
“Application Programming Interfaces” APIs — short for — are the interpreters that allow two completely different digital services or programs to talk to each other. APIs also allow government services to talk to one another, to you as the end-user, or to a third-party organization that might want to work with government data or functions.

Good APIs create an ecosystem of services that build on each other and will be the building blocks for digital government. Check out the GC API store to learn more.

day_6.title: Data Literacy
day_6.text: At its core, a data-driven organization is one that views data as a tool to predict success, build better programs and serve clients more effectively. In a data-driven organization, staff frequently encounter reports, dashboards, analyses and may have opportunities to analyse data themselves. To do so effectively, our employees need to know how to interpret and manage the data they are using each day. In order to do this, increasing data literacy is a must! How data literate are you?
